answers.answer: Hi Kris,I'm sorry but all of those medical words sound like Chinese to me.lol  I can't help you there but I'm a good listener.  I'm sorry that you have had so many problems.  We never know from day to day what life is going to throw at us.I'd sure like to learn how to throw it all back once in a while.  Hang in there and I know someone will jump in and help you understand all of this.I'll be praying,Carol

Your body has been handling a lot the last months with your treatment and all.I have done some research a while back and aspartame is neurotoxic, with some people more sensitive than others.  This means it can damage your nerves.  With your body being highly stressed with treatment and recovery you could be more than usually sensitive.Don't suspect MS.  I would think other things going on.  Look for the simplest explanations first.  MS is not a simple explanation.Cut out aspartame.  Stop chewing your gum.  Or if you must chew gum, chew the regular full sugar type.  The same goes for soft drinks and 'low calorie' foods.  Steer clear.  Eat regular sugar regular fat products.Second, make sure your doctor has cleared you for things like diabetes, which can also go undetected for a long time and can cause peripheral neuropathy symptoms.Focus on healthy as possible diet based on minimally processed foods.  Stay as active as you can.  For the sore spots, I would recommend trying massage from a qualified therapist.  Appropriate regular exercise could also help these.  Hope this response helps.Sally

Oh, and please ask your doctor to test you for B-vitamin levels.Do the testing before you start taking supplements, as supplements can skew test results.  If your levels are borderline you will need to take prescription dose B-vitamins (I take a B1, B6, B12 supplement 3x a day) or if they are low B12 injections may be given.If B-vits testing is ok, go for a good quality higher dose b-vit supplement and see if it helps anyway.  B vitamins are water soluble and won't cause harm even in higher doses.Sally

question: I was diagnosed with seminoma in January 2004. From then I received 4 cycles of BEP, and after recurrence in mediastinum - 4 cycles of BEP and radiation to my abdomen and chest. Shortly after chemotherapy in 2004 I developed peripheral neuropathy which subsided after a few months. Similarily, after radiation I had L'Hermitte symptom for 2 or 3 months. Since the completion of treatment I have had also prostatitis which seems to be healed at the moment. Sometimes I am tired at the end of the day and I have tender points in my body occassionally. Three days ago I felt some prickling(tingling?) in my both feet as if something was crawling in bottoms of my feet. When I go to bed and wake up in the morning, I have no sensation of tingling. As the day goes on, this tingling comes back and it is sensed during sitting or standing. It seems to go off during fast walking. It is not intense but it occupies my mind. I have also some tender points in my blades, near my knees and in my buttocks. I started to take Lecithin to supply some B vitamines. I wonder what is going on with this crawling feeling? Is it fibromyalgia, some deficiencies of minerals, MS or peripheral neuropathy? I chew gum every day, about one pack daily in average therefore I wonder whether there is any relation to aspartame.
title: Strange symptom
